intro: Gypsophila cappadocica, commonly known as the Cappadocian laceflower, is a flowering plant native to Turkey and parts of the Middle East. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, fern-like foliage and clusters of small, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens due to its graceful appearance and ability to attract pollinators. Gypsophila cappadocica is also valued in traditional medicine for its purported healing properties.
